title: College Assembly/High Table Dinner
requirements: Lee Woo Sing College Assembly / High Table
description: As a non-credit bearing course, it aims to enhance the general knowledge of students outside of their major studies that guest speakers are invited to share topics covering social, ethical, cultural, religious, political, artistic or aesthetic issues.
outcome: The sense of belonging to the College is enhanced.
syllabus: Guest speakers share topics covering social, ethical, cultural, religious, political, artistic or aesthetic issues.

title: College Induction Course
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College Year 1 students only;2. Not for students who have taken GEWS1012
description: This course aims at helping new students to develop an understanding and appreciation of university education and to adapt to campus life. Origins, traditions and objectives of universities, and their relationships with individual and society will be introduced. Distinctions between adult learning and juvenile learning, high-school and university studies will be elaborated. Advice and effective social and study skills will be provided to facilitate smooth transition. The Founder’s Ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) Spirit will also be covered.
outcome: After completing the course, students will be able to: ·         Learn the Founder’s ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) spirit; ·         Understand the University’s origins, traditions and objectives; ·         Learn specific study and social skills; and ·         Raise their community awareness
syllabus: 1. University Education · The meaning of university education · The role of university student   2. Personal and social skills · Personality and potential · Dining etiquette · Social etiquette and grooming · Mental wellness   3. Relationship between individual and the community  · Social equity · Meaning of social service · Biodiversity Conservation
required_readings: A. Expectation on university study  • Brinkworth, R., McCann, B. Matthews, C., Nordstrom, K. (2009). First year expectations and experiences: Student and teacher perspectives. Higher Education, 58(2), 157-173. • Crisp, G., Palmer, E., Turnbull, D., Nettelbeck, T., Ward, L., LeCouteur, A. Sarris, A., Strelan, P. & Schneider, L. (2009). First year student expectations: Results from a university-wide student survey. Journal of Univesity Teaching & Learning Practice, 6(1), 11-26. • Leung, S. A., Hou, Z. J., Gati, I. & Li, X. (2011). Effects of parental expectations and cultural-values orientation decision-making difficulties of Chinese University students. Journal of Vocational Behavior, 78, 11-20.  B. Adjustment and orientation  • Kantanis, T. (2000). The role of social transition in students’ adjustment to the first-year of university. The Journal of Institutional Research, 9(1). • Pancer, S. M., Hunsberger, B., Pratt, M. W. & Alisat, S. (2000). Cognitive complexity of expectations and adjustment to university in the first year. Journal of Adolescent Research, 15(1), 38-57. • Sevinc, S. & Gizir, C. A. (2014). Factors Negatively Affecting University Adjustment from the Views of First-Year University Students: The Case of Mersin University. Educational Sciences: Theory & Practice, 14(4), 1301-1308.  C. Group Work and Communication • Chen, Y. F., & Peng, S. S (2008). University students’ Internet use and its relationships with academic performance, interpersonal relationships, psychosocial adjustment, and self-evaluation. Cyber Psychology & Behavior, 11, 467-469. • Colbeck, C. L., Campbell, S. E. & Bjorklund, S. A. (2000). Grouping in the dark. The Journal of Higher Education, 71(1), 60-83. • Tsay, M. & Brady, M. (2010). A case study of cooperative learning and communication pedagogy: Does working in teams make a difference? Journal of the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning, 10(2), 78-89. • Troth, A. C., Jordan, P. & Lawrence, S. A. (2012). Emotional intelligence, communication competence, and student perceptions of team social cohesion. Journal of Psychoeducational Assessment, 30(4), 414-424.  D. Cultural Diversity • Hu, S. & Kuh, G. D. (2003). Diversity experiences and college student learning and personal development. Journal of College Student Development, 44(3), 320-334. • Hung, R., McClendon, J., Henderson, A., Evans, Y., Colquitt, R. & Saha, S. (2007). Student perspectives on diversity and the cultural climate at a U.S. medical school. Academic Medicine, 82(2), 184-192. • Lawrence, J. (2005). Addressing diversity in higher education: Two models for facilitating student engagement and mastery, in Higher education in a changing world, Proceedings of the 28th HERDSA Annual Conference, Sydney, 3-6 July 2005: pp 243.
recommended_readings: To be assigned by the course teachers

title: Exploration of Self, University and Hong Kong
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College Year 1 students only.;Not for students who have taken GEWS1011.
description: This course is for new students to develop an understanding and appreciation of university education and to adapt to campus life. It covers origins, traditions and objectives of universities; Founder’s ideas and the WS (Woo Sing) Spirit, relationships with individual and society. Advice and effective social and study skills are provided to facilitate smooth transition through workshop.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to • understand more about themselves, the College, the University, and Hong Kong  • learn to acquire skills in communicating with people with different background and culture

title: Special College GE Course
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College AD/HD students only.;Co-requisite: GEWS1010
description: This is a course designed especially for Lee Woo Sing second year entrants who are holders of associate degrees or higher diplomas. The objective of the course is to help students in getting a deeper understanding and reflections on the different topics of GEWS1010 College Induction Course through submission of an individual report. Students are required to take GEWS1010 in the same term for taking this course as a fulfillment of General Education requirements.

title: The Art of Leadership
requirements: For Lee Wo Sing College students only.
description: A team is a group of two or more people who have a common objective or purpose with a commitment to collective and incremental improvement. Great teams, like great leaders, are made, not born. Two concepts, trust and commitment, are the glue that holds teams together. The objective of this course is to train the students to be a leader who can foster these two aspects of the team.In this course, the students will learn the attributes of trust-building and commitment-building through lectures, workshops, and outdoor activities. The students will also participate in team projects designed by the College. By this chance, they will practise their knowledge and skills through thorough guidance by College supervisors.
outcome: • Explain the nature, purpose and structure of a team   • Equip with the individual attributes that contribute to success of teamwork   • Differentiate the roles and responsibilities within teams   • Communicate effectively in a team   • Strengthen their understanding and awareness of problem solving within a team
syllabus: 1) Lectures: Introduction of leadership and teamwork  2) Workshops and outdoor activities: Trust-building and Commitment-building  3) Team projects and presentations with guidance with College supervisors:   a) Identify the team goals, the duties and responsibilities of each team member;   b) Team meetings;   c) Accomplishing the team goal;   d) Evaluation and report; and   e) Sharing the experience to other teams.
required_readings: Characters of good leaders: 1) 露瑪・伯斯 (Bose, R)、路・佛斯特 (Faust, L.) (2012)。貧民窟裡的領導 : 德蕾莎修女的管理智慧 (Mother Teresa, CEO：unexpected principles for practical leadership) (朱道凱譯) (一版)。台北市 : 天下雜誌股份有限公司。 2) 岩田松雄 (2013)。成為讓部屬願意追隨的上司：51個帶人先帶心的領導力 (ついていきたい」と思われるリーダーになる51の考え方) (劉滌昭譯)。台灣：悅知文化。   Servant Leadership:  3) 詹姆士・杭特 (Hunter, J. C.) (2010)。僕人－修道院的領導啟示錄 (The Servant: A Simple Story About the True Essence of Leadership) (張沛文譯)。台灣：商周出版。 4) 詹姆士．杭特 (Hunter, J. C.) (2010)。僕人－修練與實踐 (The World’s Most Powerful Leadership Principle) (李紹廷譯)。台灣：商周出版。
recommended_readings: Characters of good leaders: 1) 約翰．麥斯威爾 (Maxwell, J. C.) (2008)。360度全方位領導。台灣：英柏爾。 2) Maxwell, J. C. (2008). Leadership gold: lessons learned from a lifetime of leading. Nashville, Tenn. : Thomas Nelson Publishers.

locations: Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R

title: General History of China
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for History Majors.;3. Not for students who have taken UGEA2230.
description: This course aims at introducing the main course of changes in Chinese history and the value of Chinese cultural heritage. Through lectures and discussions, it covers major issues in development of Chinese history. Examples of the topics include the origin of Chinese culture, milestones in dynastic history, intellectual thoughts and social structures. Field trip and tutorial help students to understand the relationship between Chinese history and Hong Kong development. After taking this course, students are expected to develop critical thinking and analysis skills in a historical context, and further interests in the learning of Chinese culture.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to • acquire a general knowledge and understanding in Chinese history.  • appreciate how the humanistic values and societal structures evolve and develop from traditional to modern China.  • criticize and evaluate issues in contemporary Chinese communities in a historic context.  • identify the relationship between Chinese history and Hong Kong development.  • develop further interests in the study of Chinese culture.
syllabus: 第一章 引論：讀國史的信念 第二章 中國文化之起源  第三章 中國封建與秦漢大一統政治  第四章 魏晉分裂與世家大族政治  第五章 隋唐盛世與三省制  第六章 思想與學術文化：先秦諸子與儒家傳統  第七章 兩宋貧弱與政治革新  第八章 明代專制政治  第九章 思想與學術文化：宋明理學  第十章 清代部族統治  第十一章 近代中國的挫折與圖強  第十二章 中國復興之路 第十三章 總結
required_readings: 第一章 引論：讀國史的信念 1. 錢穆：《國史大綱•引論》，臺北：國立編譯館，1984年，頁一至二九。  第二章 中國文明之起源  1. 張光直：〈中國相互作用圈與文明的形成〉。見《慶祝蘇秉琦考古五十五年論文集》，北京：文物出版社，1989年，頁1-23。   第三章 中國封建與秦漢大一統政治  1. 許倬雲：《西周史》，台北﹕聯經出版事業公司，1984年，頁139-173。  2. 顧頡剛：《秦漢方士與儒生》，上海：上海世紀出版集團，2005年，頁1-70。   第四章 魏晉分裂與世家大族社會  1. 錢穆：《國史大綱》，第四編〈魏晉南北朝之部〉選讀。  2. 杜正勝：〈編戶齊民——傳統的家族與家庭〉。見《吾土與吾民》，台北：聯經出版事業公司，1982年，頁7-36。  第五章 隋唐盛世與三省制  1. 錢穆：《國史大綱》，第五編〈隋唐五代之部〉選讀。  2. 錢穆：《中國歷代政治得失》，第二講，〈唐代•唐代政府組織〉，台北：東大圖書有限公司，1977年，頁41-56。   第六章 思想與學術文化：先秦諸子與儒家傳統  1. Kwong-loi Shun, Mencius and Early Chinese Thought. Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press, 1997.   第七章 兩宋貧弱與政治革新  1. 錢穆：《國史大綱》，第六編〈兩宋之部〉選讀。  2. 漆俠：《王安石變法》，上海：上海人民出版社，1961年。   第八章 明代專制政治  1. 吳晗：《朱元璋傳》，北京：生活・讀書・新知三聯書店，1965年。   第九章 思想與學術文化：宋明理學  1. 余英時：《朱熹的歷史世界：宋代士大夫政治文化的硏究》，上篇〈緒說〉第二、三、四節，台北：允晨文化實業股份有限公司，2003年，頁32-159。  2. 錢穆：《宋子學提綱》，台北：東大圖書公司，1971年。   第十章 清代部族統治  1. 錢穆：《國史大綱》，第八編〈清代之部〉選讀。   第十一章 近代中國的挫折與圖強  1. Immanuel C. Y. Hsü, The Rise of Modern China, Chapter 15 & Chapter 21, New York: Oxford University Press, 2000, pp355-386 & pp493-513；或中譯本：徐中約著，計秋楓、朱慶葆、茅家琦、錢乘旦校：《中國近代史》，第15 & 第21章，香港：中文大學出版社，2001年，頁359-388 & 頁495-515。   第十二章 中國復興之路  1. Jonathan D. Spence, The Search for Modern China, Chapter 22 & Chapter 25, New York: W. W. Norton & Company, 1990, pp627-652 & pp712-747.   第十三章 總結  1. 許倬雲：《萬古江河：中國歷史文化的轉折與開展》，第八章〈百年蹣跚〉，香港：中華書局，2006年，頁399-457。
recommended_readings: 1. 錢穆：《國史大綱》。臺北：國立編譯館，1984年。 2. 黃仁宇：《中國大歷史》。臺北：聯經出版事業公司，1993年。  3. 余英時：《中國思想傳統的現代詮釋》。臺北：聯經出版事業公司，1987年。  4. 白壽彝(總主編)：《中國通史》(全12卷)。上海：上海人民出版社，1989-1999。  5. Shun, Kwong-loi, Mencius and Early Chinese Thought. Stanford, Calif.: Stanford University Press, 1997.

title: China and The World
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
description: Napoleon Bonaparte once said of China: “China is a sleeping lion. Let her sleep, for when she wakes she will move the world.” Today, China has risen to become the second largest global economic power; and some experts even predicted that her economy is poised to overtake the US economy by year-2035. Is Napoleon’s prophecy going to come true? China has remained an enigma to the rest of the world. Traditional China’s accomplishments towards medicine, painting, architecture, martial art music and dance had impressed the world and her inventions such as paper, gunpowder, compass, and printing had helped move Europe to the modern age. This course aims to examine the evolvement of the Chinese civilization and factors affecting how China interacts with the rest of the world. It will also explore the extent and impacts of intercultural exchanges between China and the world. The course will also look at the role Hong Kong played in China’s interaction with foreign powers in the past and assess opportunities afforded Hong Kong in the implementation of the Chinese “One Belt, one Road” initiative.In conclusion, the course will assess the swift rise of contemporary China, and the aftermaths brought by her rapid industrialization. The course will try to answer if China will fulfil Napoleon’s prophecy.

title: Future of Food: Plant-based Living
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
description: This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to plant-based lifestyle. Particular thematic issues such as global warming and pollution, food crisis, diet and health, animal rights, social justice as well as green economy related to livestock industry and food system will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of omnivore diet and lifestyle to their personal life, the animals and the planet as a whole.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to  • Examine the main concepts related to plant-based lifestyle, such as types of plant-based diet, development and consciousness in Hong Kong, modern livestock industry and global warming, correlation between diet and health in terms of nutrition, Chinese and Western medical science, animal rights of food animals and non-food animals and marketing direction of this movement • Differentiate the vegetarian food culture among countries and identify the variety of vegetarian.  • Be exposed to the main controversies resulted from livestock industry, e.g. health, global warming and pollution, food crisis, animal rights, social justice, etc. • Have the ability to form independent idea and justification about the causes, norms, impact and controversies of the animal-consuming culture and lifestyle by applying the concepts covered in the course • Have the ability to explore and apply plant-based alternatives towards current animal-consuming culture and lifestyle
syllabus: 1. Why we eat pigs but love cats? 2. Does taking public transport help us to reduce carbon footprint? 3. How many chickens do our planet carries? 4. How about the protein? 5. Cigarettes Vs Sausage – Which does more harm to our body? 6. Doesn’t eating vegetables makes our body too “Han”?  7. Outing: Plant-based grocery shopping and restaurants 8. Omnivore or plant-based – Is this a personal choice?  9. Keeping pets means loving animals?  10. Why vegetarians and vegans are still minorities? 11. Where do we go from plant-based diet?
required_readings: 1. Why we eat pigs but love cats? Melanie Joy PhD, Why We Love Dogs, Eat Pigs, and Wear Cows: An Introduction to Carnism, Conari Press, San Francisco, 2010, Chapter 1, “To Love or to Eat?”, pp. 23 – 36  2. Does taking public transport help us to reduce carbon footprint? Gerber, P.J., Steinfeld, H., Henderson, B., Mottet, A., Opio, C., Dijkman, J., Falcucci, A. & Tempio, G., Tackling climate change through livestock – A global assessment of emissions and mitigation opportunities, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Rome, 2013, Chapter 3, “The aggregate picture”, pp. 15-21 < http://www.fao.org/docrep/018/i3437e/i3437e.pdf>  3. How many chickens do our planet carries? WWF, Appetite for Destruction, 2007, < https://www.wwf.org.uk/sites/default/files/2017-10/WWF_AppetiteForDestruction_Summary_Report_SignOff.pdf>  4. How about the protein? Vesanto Melina, Winston Craig and Susan Levin, “Position of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics: Vegetarian Diets”, Journal of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, Volume 116, Issue 12, 2016, pp. 1970–1980.  5. Cigarettes Vs Sausage – Which does more harm to our body? Ornish, D., et al., Intensive lifestyle changes for reversal of coronary heart disease. JAMA, Volume 280, Issue 23, 1998, pp.2001-7  6. Doesn’t eating vegetables makes our body too “Han”?  Yu M. Lee, “中醫看素食”, 李大夫·上醫方, 2017, http://leeyuming.com/素食中醫師/ .  7. Omnivore or plant-based – Is this a personal choice?  David Fraser, Animal ethics and animal welfare science: bridging the two cultures, Applied Animal Behaviour Science, Volume 65, 1999, pp. 171–189  8. Keeping pets means loving animals? G. A. Bradshaw, Elephants in Circuses: Analysis of Practice, Policy, and Future, Animals and Society Institute, 2007.   9. Why vegetarians and vegans are still minorities? Tobias Leenaert, How to create a vegan world: A Pragmatic Approach, Lantern Books, New York, 2017, Chapter 4, “Environment: Make Things Easier”, pp. 81 – 110.  10. Where do we go from plant-based diet? Will Tuttle, Ph.D., World Peace diet: Eating for Spiritual Health and Social Harmony, 10th ed.. Lantern Books, New York, 2016, Chapter 14, “Evolve or Dissolve” pp.220 – 239.
recommended_readings: 1. How about the protein? Mangels R, Messina V, Messina M, The Dietitian’s Guide to Vegetarian Diets: Issues and Applications, 3rd ed.. Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2011.  2. Cigarettes Vs Sausage – Which does more harm to our body? McMicheal AJ., Food, nutrition, physical activity and cancer prevention. Authoritative report from World Cancer Research Fund provides global update. Public Health Nutr., Volume 11, Issue 7, 2008 Jul, pp.762-3  3. Why vegetarians and vegans are still minorities? Tobias Leenaert, How to create a vegan world: A Pragmatic Approach, Lantern Books, New York, 2017, Chapter 2, “The Call to Action: What Do We Ask People to Do?”, pp. 29 – 53.

locations: Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R

title: Evolution of Universal Communication: Debate and Application
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
description: This course examines the nature of manner and etiquette systems in the context of interpersonal as well as intercultural communications through exploring its history and development. As part of the social norms, manner and etiquette systems seem to be more universal with increasing socializations in a more globalized world, especially in the business sector. There are still ongoing debates that some countries still preserve their own manner and etiquette systems in some splendid ceremonies and events. This course further studies the factors and socialization processes that shape manner and etiquette system, while specific application will refer to the culture of business in term of practices and behaviours.

title: Nature's Classroom: Field Studies of Nature's Genius in Biodiversity
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
description: This course aims to introduce nature’s genius in the diversity of flora and fauna of Hong Kong and other places. It is specially designed for students in their second year of study or above. The goal is to raise students' awareness of nature’s hidden beauty and genius, including biodiversity and biomimicry. Coursework includes lectures and outings led by experts in their fields, field trip reports, analysis and interpretation of wildlife films in class, feedback on video-clips, a multimedia art exercise, and a biodiversity quiz. Students will learn to appreciate and treasure biodiversity through guided tree walks, bird watching, butterfly photography, and powerful ideas of Nature as our mentor, measure and model in solving human problems. No prior knowledge of biodiversity, or training in multimedia or photography is required, but a sense of wonder, a spirit of inquiry, and passionate curiosity in Nature’s genius.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:  1. appreciate the importance of learning from nature as their mentor, measure, and model and to apply what they learn to solve real-life problems  2. tell others some of the biodiversity hotspots in Hong Kong and suggest ways to protect them  3. develop a spirit of inquiry, and draw on Nature’s genius in the idea of biomimicry  4. tell the human impact on climate change and its disastrous consequences on biodiversity  5. find and show compassion for all living creatures and Nature as whole and take actions to save endangered species and ecosystems
syllabus: Major concepts and topics to be covered include:  1. The concept of biodiversity and topics related to Hong Kong as examined by practical field studies  a. Hong Kong Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (HKBSAP)  b. Trees of Hong Kong  c. Birds of Hong Kong  d. Butterflies of Hong Kong  2. The concept of biomimicry in relation to biodiversity and evaluation of its applications  a. Learning from Nature  b. Biomimicry in action   3. Biodiversity and Sustainable Development  a. Design for sustainability (e.g. visiting an experimental farm with aquaponics)  b. Ecological solutions   4. Biodiversity Conservation and Climate Change  a. Global warming since the Industrial Revolution  b. Biodiversity decline factors: H.I.P.P.O.  i. Habitat loss (including climate change and extreme weather)  ii. Invasive Species  iii. Pollution  iv. Population explosion  v. Over-harvesting  Fieldwork: There will be two field trips to Hong Kong’s rural areas including country parks.
required_readings: Biodiversity  1. AFCD. (Jan. 2016). Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan (BSAP) for Hong Kong: Public Consultation Paper Document (53 pages). Both English and Chinese versions are available at http://www.afcd.gov.hk/english/conservation/con_bsap/bsap_consultation/bsap_consultation_documen t.html  2. locations: Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R

title: Selected Topics in WS College General Education
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
description: This course is designed to discuss selected topics of current interest in College General Education of Lee Woo Sing College. The specific topics to be covered in an academic year will be selected in accordance with the general objectives of the LWS College general education program, in consideration of the expertise of the teachers available and the interests of the students, and will be announced before the start of the academic year. Advisory: For Year 2 or 3 College students only.

title: Innovation in Service Industry
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for Hotel and Tourism Management majors or Hospitality and Real Estate majors or students who have taken HTMG1010.
description: This course provides an understanding of the nature of innovation related to the growth, success and future development of the service industry on the local and global scales. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of how both anticipated and unanticipated changes may influence tourism, hospitality and MICE (i.e. Meeting, Incentive, Convention and Exhibition). The roles of innovation and creativity in responding to change are also emphasized. Consequently, the course addresses aspects of key management problems, needs, developments and approaches that effectively utilize technology and innovation in the service industry. It also encompasses an understanding of various information and other technological methods utilized in the functional areas of development, operations, management, marketing and financial management.

title: Experiencing the Kunqu and Peking Opera
description: Kunqu and Peking Opera are Chinese classical traditions and cultures. The aim of this course is to nurture students’ appreciation ability and to deepen their understanding on Kunqu and Peking Opera. This course serves as a bridge to further study at an advanced level and encourages future participation on Kunqu and Peking Opera performance.

title: Experiencing the Kunqu and Peking Opera
description: Kunqu and Peking Opera are Chinese classical traditions and cultures. The aim of this course is to nurture students' appreciation ability and to deepen their understanding on Kunqu and Peking Opera.This course serves as a foundation to further study at an advanced level and encourages future participation in Kunqu and Peking Opera performance.

title: Understanding Globalization
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for students who have taken UGEC2514 or UGEC2990/ANTH2520
description: This course helps students to understand the major concepts, theories, debates and reflections related to globalization. Particular thematic issues such as economy, environment and sport as well as non-traditional security issues in the fields of humanitarian intervention, terrorism, nuclear proliferation, drug trafficking and global health will be examined. The course encourages students to observe and evaluate the impacts of globalization to their personal life as well as the role of Hong Kong between the East and the West in the era of globalization.

title: Food Psychology and Healthy Eating
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for Hotel and Tourism Management majors or Hospitality and Real Estate majors.
description: You are what you eat. In modern society, food consumption not only fulfils basic human physiological needs but also greatly impacts people’s fitness and wellbeing. This course helps students to understand the psychological processes and factors underlying their food choice and eating behaviour and acquire knowledge and skills in developing healthy eating habits in college and beyond. Main topics covered in this course include the development of eating behavior, social influences on eating, food choice and consumption behavior, eating disorders and treatments as well as developing healthy eating habits.

title: History from Words: Experience the Beauty of Literature
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for students of Department of Chinese Language and Literature.
description: This course will give a survey of the development of modern Chinese literature. By reading selected works of major authors, this course investigates the thoughts, the artistry and the significance of modern Chinese short stories, novellas and poems. Besides, it gives a survey of the development of Hong Kong literature by reading the works of major authors. The relationships between literature and history, as well as between literature and society, will be emphasized. The artistic quality of Hong Kong literature and its place in modern Chinese literature will be evaluated.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to  1. describe the general contemporary history of China and Hong Kong through reading modern literature  2. master the concept of post-modern history and understand the mediating role of narrative text in historical narrative  3. recognize the humanism, value of diversity and creativity through literature reading  4. cultivate the habit of reading literatures
syllabus: The course will cover the following topics of modern literature:  1. Chinese Poetry 2. Chinese Fiction  3. HK Literature  4. Modern Literature 5. Autobiography / Biography of Modern Historical Figure in China
required_readings: 1. 緒論及課程簡介 • 王德威：《想像中國的方法：小說、歷史、敘事》，北京：三聯書店，1998年 2. 想像與現實 • 魯迅：〈藥〉，《吶喊》，香港：三聯書店，1999年； • 沈從文：《阿麗絲中國漫遊記》，海南：南海出版公司，2000年 3. 小人物的歷史 • 余華：《活著》，台北：麥田出版，2007年 4. 第一身自傳式敘事 • 季羨林：《牛棚雜憶》，香港：三聯書店，1999年； • 楊絳：《我們仨》，香港：牛津大學出版社，2003年 5. 另一種歷史 • 王小波：《黃金時代》，台北：自由之丘，2012年； • 余華：《一九八六年》，廣東：花城出版社，2013年 6. 尋根文學與歷史 • 莫言《紅高粱》，中國青年出版社， 2004年 7. 烏有史 • 陳冠中：《建豐二年——新中國烏有史》，香港：牛津大學出版社，2015年 8. 魔幻寫實香港史 • 西西〈浮城誌異〉，《我城》，台北：洪範書店，1999年 9. 地下社會與殖民史 • 馬家輝：《龍頭鳳尾》，台北：新經典文化，2016年 10. 陰性角度香港史 • 黃碧雲：《烈女圖》，香港：天地圖書，1999年 11. 歷史與流行文化 • 李碧華：《胭脂扣》，香港：天地圖書，1985年； • 陳慧：《拾香記》，香港：七字頭出版社，1999年 12. 文化史 • 董啟章：《天工開物．栩栩如真》，台北：麥田出版，2005年

title: The Rise of Populism in Europe
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for students who have taken GPAD3160.
description: This course covers a wide variety of material and is highly relevant in understanding rapid changes in Global and Comparative European Politics. Part I of the course provides a brief historical background to European politics and sets the scene for the course, in examining theoretically how contemporary ‘populism’ is defined and conceptualized in the 21st century political landscape. Part II of the course provides the main focus of the course, in focusing on the main causes and drivers that have led to the growth of (a) radical right-wing populism and (b) radical left-wing populism. Three key approaches are drawn on in Part II of the course, with comparative studies, survey research (public opinion) and case studies across Western Europe and Central-Eastern Europe allowing students to understand about the diversity and variations of populism in the contemporary political landscape. Part III of the course introduces students to critical debates and evaluations on the ‘rise’ of populism and just how important understanding this political phenomenon is for (a) the implications for contemporary democracy and governance in EU member states, alongside (b) how populism on the ‘right’ and ‘left’ of the political spectrum is challenging the future EU project. Part III of the course also draws briefly on comparisons between the primary causes of ‘populism’ in the European context, to the causes of ‘localism’ in the Hong Kong context.The final part of the course also revisits the premise and assumption made in Part I of the course, about the historical stability of the European political landscape by outlining how a shift has taken place, with ‘a new form of politics’ now existing in European politics. Stability and patterns of partisan alignment have now been replaced by instability and widespread patterns of electoral volatility.

title: Hong Kong Myths
requirements: For Lee Woo Sing College students only.
description: As an international city, Hong Kong has been praised in world class financial services; one of the most efficient governments in the globe; a vibrant and pluralistic globalized city which can serve as the bridge between China and the West even after the handover in 1997. The above Hong Kong myths are valid to some extent, but very often people in Hong Kong have neglected the successful driving forces behind. More importantly, could Hong Kong’s successful development be sustained in a long run? This is an introductory course on contemporary Hong Kong issues. This course applies an interdisciplinary approach and aims at introducing students to basic concepts from Hong Kong’s economics and trade, to administrative and political system of Hong Kong, as well as the role of Hong Kong in international relations.

title: The Beauty of Chinese Painting
requirements: 1. For Lee Woo Sing College students only.;2. Not for Fine Arts Majors.
description: This course introduces the materials and tools, techniques in brushwork, ink tone variations, and colouring to beginning students of Chinese painting. It also focuses on the techniques of painting in an expressive manner i.e. in the literati tradition of “writing the idea”. In this regard, Chinese calligraphy and painting techniques, as well as the forms of expression are covered.
outcome: 通過修讀本科，學生應可： 1.瞭解與初步掌握中國畫基本的工具，為表達自己的心境與想法打下一定的基礎； 2.整個科目貫穿書法的學習與練習，能以書入畫，於畫作題字； 3.瞭解東西方文化不同的繪畫表達，知道各自長處與特點，也可以借鑒西方藝術表達方式； 4.體會東方美學精神，學會在「虛白處做文章」，如何體察自己的內心，尋找合適的表達語言，做到「無中生有」。
syllabus: 內容:  1. 對工具如筆、墨、硯、紙的瞭解與使用方法，線條練習與熟悉水與墨的相斥相融。 2. 從書法入手，從歷代書法源變中感受與欣賞書法之美，體現毛筆的魅力與筆力。 3. 中國畫的符號象徵一一《芥子園畫譜》介紹，為何貢布里希《藝術與視覺》推崇為「中國標準繪畫教程」？學會一些物象的表現方法，學會「看到自己會畫的東西」。 4. 中國山水畫導賞與分析，欣賞中國歷代優秀山水畫，從中找到自己的喜愛與方向。 5. 介紹西方繪畫的特點與流變，從東西方繪畫的特點看東方意韻的表達，也學會吸收西方繪畫的意象表達元素。 6. 欣賞與理解中國與筆墨的趣味，通過撞水、撞色、撞粉……等實踐，初步體味水墨的豐富味道。 7. 通過不斷創新的中國山水畫技法，瞭解如「拓印」等手法，學會逆反思維，增加與豐富中國畫的表現力。 8. 介紹近代中國山水畫創新大家劉國松的畫作，通過他的創作拓寬我們的思路與視野。 9. 介紹與欣賞中國畫家走向世界的成功代表人物趙無極，從他的創作理念與實戰中學會中西交融，洋為中用。 10. 課外寫生，經過一段時間的嘗試與實踐，我們走出室外，到大自然、到山野中尋找符合內心表達的物象加以表達。 11. 寫生創作，把上周外出寫生的素材加以整理，把之理想化，形成新的視覺圖像。 12. 無中生有，從心中尋出聽思所想，畫出心中的那個意象，直抒胸臆……這種抒懷會令人產生淋灕的痛快。 13. 超以象外一一這是中國畫最高的境界，也是東方藝術的精髓，通過十二周的課程學習，最後，有一個階段性的綜合、表現與發揮。
required_readings: 中國山水畫發展史 1.《中國名畫博物館》，全景博物館叢書編委會，海燕出版社，2002 (頁438-439; 頁514-519; 頁538-542; 頁543-544) 2.《中國歷代繪畫圖譜/山水》，周衛明編，上海人民美術出版社，1996 (頁1-7) 3.《中國美學史》，李澤厚、劉綱紀著，安徽文藝出版社，1999 (頁20-33)  書法 1.《中國書法博物館》，南兆旭、全景博物館叢書編委會，海燕出版社，2003 (頁1-17) 2.《中國繪畫》，楊飛主編，中國文史出版社，2004 (頁2-20；66-67)  中國山水畫技巧 1.《芥子園畫傳》（康熙版原大全彩），李漁編，江西美術出版社，2011 (頁88-91；130-131；184-185；270-271；346-347) 2.《清代山水畫風》，張曉凌、凍月編，重慶出版社，1995 (頁4-5；18；28-29；120-121) 3.《中國現代山水畫全集》，賈德江主編，河北教育出版社，2002 (頁22-25, 36-39) 4.《中國畫歷代名家技法圖譜/皴法》，盧輔聖主編，上海書畫出版社，1990 (頁3-5；14-15；78-79；112-113；124-125)  中國山水畫畫家 1.《中國傳世山水畫》，王佔英編，內家古人民出版社，2002 (頁4-5；26-27) 2.《趙無極自畫像》趙無極、梵思娃.馬凱著，劉俐譯，台灣藝術家出版社，1996 (頁50-55; 153-167) 3.《當代名家山水畫稿》，張復興、趙衛等，河南美術出版社，2001 (頁1-15；112-121) 4.《劉國松的中國現代畫之路》，林木著，四川美術出版社，2007 (頁1-6)
recommended_readings: 中國山水畫發展史 1.《文化的價值》，維特根斯坦著，重慶出版社，2006 2.《中國美術簡史》，中央美術學院美術史系、中國美術史教研室編，中國青年出版社，2002  書法 1.《中國書法博物館》，南兆旭、全景博物館叢書編委會，海燕出版社，2003 2.《中國繪畫》，楊飛主編，中國文史出版社，2004  中國山水畫技巧 1.《當代中國山水畫集》，河南美術出版社，1997 2.《當代中國山水畫、油畫風景展作品集》，廣西美術出版社，1999 3.《滄桑入畫》，吳冠中著，學林出版社，1997  中國山水畫畫家 1.《盧延光山水畫》，新世紀出版社，2005 2.《東山魁夷散文選》，陳德文譯，百花文藝出版社，1989

locations: Lee W.S., Agnes H.Y. Lau Sem R

title: College Capstone Course
requirements: For students of Lee Woo Sing College.
description: This course requires the final year students of different disciplines to conduct small group research and discussion to apply what they have learnt to various cross-disciplinary issues. Students are encouraged to cultivate critical thinking and judgment, and to gain valuable experience in building effective partnership with other members through cooperation.Career development, sharing with professionals, job and career prospects, and good practices in job applications will also be covered.* Subject to approval by the Committee, students may take this course prior to their final year of studies.
